    Nairobi MCAs issue ultimatum to evict matatus from fuel stations

    County Assembly cites safety risks and urban congestion as matatus crowd petrol stations illegally.

    By Zawadi Intel Staff | Dec 1, 2025

    Matatus parked at a Nairobi fuel station, raising safety concerns. ¬© Zawadi Intel

    The Nairobi County Assembly has issued a stern ultimatum to matatu operators, demanding the immediate removal of public service vehicles (PSVs) from fuel stations. Officials argue that the practice poses significant safety risks, including fire hazards and traffic congestion.

    MCAs highlighted that petrol stations are not designed to serve as parking bays, and overcrowding by matatus has created dangerous conditions for motorists and pedestrians alike. The ultimatum reflects growing frustration with the lack of compliance among operators.

    Resistance from Operators

    Matatu operators have resisted the directive, citing convenience for passengers and economic benefits for their businesses. They argue that fuel stations provide accessible pick-up points, especially in areas lacking designated bus termini.

    Negotiations between the County Assembly and matatu associations are ongoing, with both sides seeking a compromise that balances safety with economic realities.

    Government Enforcement Plans

    Authorities have warned that enforcement actions will be taken if matatus fail to comply. Plans include increased patrols, fines, and possible revocation of operating licenses for repeat offenders.

    ‚ÄúPublic safety cannot be compromised for convenience. Fuel stations are not bus stops.‚Äù ‚Äî Nairobi MCA

    Community Support

    Local residents have expressed support for the initiative, noting that the congestion around fuel stations has worsened traffic jams and created unsafe conditions. Community leaders believe the move could improve urban management and restore order in Nairobi‚Äôs transport system.

    Looking Ahead

    As the deadline approaches, stakeholders are urged to cooperate for mutual benefits. The County Assembly insists that compliance will enhance city livability, reduce risks, and set a precedent for better urban planning.
